title: EuroFab
text:
Why urban fabric
Cities take up around 3% of the planet’s land but are home to more than half of humanity and responsible for 75% of carbon emissions1.
United Nations (2020)

title: EuroFab
text:
Why urban fabric
Urban fabric, the spatial layout of the physical elements that make up a city, mediates most activities their residents undertake, from heating their homes to accessing services, jobs and opportunities through sustainable modes of transport.

title: EuroFab
text:
Why urban fabric
Easily available, comparable, and dynamic information on urban fabric would unlock new ways of understanding how cities are constantly evolving, what it means for their sustainability, and how effective policies can be designed to steer development in desirable directions.

title: EuroFab
text:
Why now
In 2023, UN Habitat included urban fabric as one of the key ingredients required for effective sustainable design1
UN Habitat (2024)

title: EuroFab
text:
Why now
There are currently very few instances of detailed, consistent, and scalable measurements of urban fabric and virtually none of them provide insight into its change over time.

title: EuroFab
text:
EuroFab vision
EuroFab paves the road for a world where stakeholders, from local authorities to supranational organisations, are able to track and monitor the pattern of urban development in detail directly relevant for planning and at scale.

we’re not there yet

title: EuroFab
text: Objectives

title: EuroFab
text:
State of the Art
Classifications of urban form fall, broadly, into two categories.


rich, detailed, and hyper-local classifications
simpler, coarser, large-scale classifications

title: EuroFab
text:
Proposed approach
Urban morphometrics + computer vision.
A balance between generalisation and detail.
More granularity than existing large-scale classifications.
Scalability to much larger regions than traditional hyper-local classifications

title: EuroFab
text:
What
Ensure and maximise the policy relevance, usability and further applications of the outputs of the project.
International comparability of the data products and their derived indicators.
Comparison of the outputs of the project with other already existing classifications endorsed by international organisations and applied by National Statistical Offices (e.g. the classification of human settlements DEGURBA).

title: EuroFab
text:
How
OECD Geospatial Lab and OECD technical expertise
“Producer” stakeholders, mainly belonging to the scientific community (working on the production of data flows and data products close or relevant to the expected deliverable of EuroFab).
“User” stakeholders, wide range of potential user of the data produced by EuroFab, interested in applying it for the definition of policy-relevant indicators and characterised by various degrees of technical competencies.

title: EuroFab
text:
Six Work Packages


WP000 Project Management and Communication
WP100 Collaborative Stakeholder Requirements Consolidation
WP200 Iterative Algorithm Design and Data Collection Sprints
WP300 Incremental Development and Processing Algorithm Implementation
WP400 Verification of Novel Processing Capability in Representative Use Case and Results Dissemination
WP500 Large-scale Inference and Operationalization Strategy Elaboration

title: EuroFab
text:
Events

Week 1 of November 2024:

Networking event at WUF12 (Cairo, Egypt) – pending selection process

Week 4 of January 2025:

Week 4 of April 2025:

Stakeholder Workshop III

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
section: Interplay between population and urban form
text:
Interplay between population and urban form
Understand built-up patterns of housing types and the ability of different population groups to inhabit them.

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Methods
Dimensinality reduction of census data
Geographicaly weighted prediction models

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Morphometric classification
Quantitative identification of urban form types.
Based on similar morphological characteristics shared by street segments and building footprints.
Focuses on geometry and spatial configuration within the urban fabric.

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Spatial relationship
Who lives in different types of the urban form? How does it differ across the country?
Is there a specific relationship between a group of people and an urban form type? How does it differ regionally?
How to asses this relationship?

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Census processing
Variable selection - no leakage, no nested variables, repetition etc.
Data normalization and standardization
Dimensionality reduction

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Dimesionality reduction
Principal Component Analysis
Factor Analysis
Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Geographically weighted modelling
Global models assume the same relationship between predictors and target classes across the entire dataset
They do not account for the geographic variation in the relationship
Geographically weighted models capture this by applying local models rather than a single global model.

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Geographically weighted classification
Similar in concept to Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR).
Categorical or class-based outcomes.
Separate classifier for each location using data weighted by geographic proximity.

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Modelling
Outputs from dimensionality reduction → Geographically weighted Logistic Regression & Random Forest Classification

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Results



F1-macro score

title: Spatial modelling of the relationship between the urban form and population data
text:
Conclusion
Relationship does differ geographically.
Specific relationship between population characteristics and urban form types.
Dimensionality reduction or cluster analysis?
Work still in progress, would appreciate some feedback!

text: Araldi, A. and Fusco, G. (2025), Multi-Level Street-Based Analysis of the Urban Fabric: Developments for a Nationwide Taxonomy. Geographical Analysis, 57: 270-301.

text: Fleischmann, M., Feliciotti, A., Romice, O., & Porta, S. (2021). Methodological foundation of a numerical taxonomy of urban form. Environment and Planning B, 49(4), 1283-1299.

title: Understanding Urban Form
text: Enclosed Tessellation Cells

title: Understanding Urban Form
text: Measured characteristics

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
Gradually Loosening Spatial Restrictions
Framework for hierarchical spatial clustering relying on:

Nested intermediate aggregations
Nested spatial restrictions for each aggregation
Hierarchical operationalisations to create the aggregations, given the restrictions

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
Three levels of aggregations

ETCs to morphotopes
Morphotopes to Regional Morphotope Types
Regional Morphotope Types clusters to Morphotope Types (taxa)

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
Morphotope


“the smallest urban locality obtaining distinctive character among their neighbours from their particular combination of constituent morphological elements.”

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
Three levels of spatial restrictions

Immediate - only immediate neighbors can be part of the same cluster.
Regional - only neighbours within the same region can be combined. A region is contiguous land around buildings where the nearest neighbour is at maximum 500 meters away.
Global - no spatial restrictions

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
Regions

Region around Prague

title: Understanding Urban Form
text: Three algorithms

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
1. Spatial Adaptive Agglomerative Clustering (\(SA^3\))

Compute a full regionalisation tree with any sklearn.hierarchy.AgglomerativeClustering algorithm and spatial restrictions imposed by a libpysal.graph.Graph or libpysal.weights.W.

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
2. Regional clusters

Complete linkage applied to all the morphotopes within a single region.

title: Understanding Urban Form
text:
3. Bisecting K-Means

Step 1. - the whole dataset is split into two clusters by performing a kmeans clustering with K=2.
Step \(N\). - the algorithm splits each of the clusters from the \(N-1\) iteration into two further clusters, again using a kmeans clustering with K=2.
The algorithm stops when each cluster has at most 2 members, and the taxonomy is built based on the splits.

title: From a building to a region
text:
What is urban morphometrics


A study of urban form through the means of quantitative assessment of its constituent elements.


Conceptually similar to historico-geographical approach.
Methodologically embedded in spatial data science and geography.
